Base.name: ADD/ADHD
Base.description1: a chronic difference that includes difficulty maintaining attention, hyperactivity, and impulsive behaviour
Base.description2: people with ADD/ADHD may experience difficulties following through on instructions and orgainizing tasks or activities
Base.description3: those with ADD/ADHD are often more creative and spontaneous

Base.name: Dyslexia
Base.description1: signs of dyslexia include trouble reading, writing, and spelling
Base.description2: people with dyslexia may have difficulty learning a foreign language and/or have poor handwriting
Base.description3: people who have dyslexia are often more spatially aware and creative

Base.name: Dyscalculia
Base.description1: this difference in learning makes it difficult to understand arithmetic
Base.description2: people with dyscalculia may have trouble reading analog clocks, working with budgets and timelines, performing basic math skills and differentiating between numbers and values
Base.description3: struggling with matricies in algebra or flunking calculus doesn't usually mean you have dyscalculia; it affects more basic arithmetic facts such as simple addition

Base.name: Dysgraphia
Base.description1: a learning disability that affects children and adults, and interferes with practically all aspects of the writing process, including spelling, legibility, word spacing and sizing, and expression
Base.description2: people have trouble forming letters shapes and a tight, awkward, or painful grip on a pencil
Base.description3: dysgraphia symptoms typically change over time

Base.name: Disassociative Disorder
Base.description1: this disorder generates feelings of unreality, as if one is detached from their own mind, body, self, and/or surroundings
Base.description2: during episodes, one is aware what one is experiencing is abnormal
Base.description3: the disorder can result in long-term memory gaps, forgetting personal information, or past events

Base.name: Tourette’s Syndrome
Base.description1: a disorder of the nervous system that causes the individual to make involuntary sounds and movements called ‘tics’
Base.description2: Tourette’s is characterized by multiple motor tics and at least one vocal (phonic) tic
Base.description3: some people with Tourette’s have a gift for hyper-focusing on a task

Base.name: Sleep Apnea
Base.description1: this condition causes pauses in the breath or shallow breathing during sleep
Base.description2: this is a common and often chronic condition that disrupts deep sleep causing people to be tired during the day
Base.description3: people who experience sleep apnea snore loudly

Base.name: Amputee
Base.description1: an amputee is someone who has partially or entirely lost a limb
Base.description2: reasons for an amputation can include severe injuries, cancerous tumors, acute infections and thickening of nerve tissue or frostbite
Base.description3: amputees can use artificial limbs and assistive devices to compensate for their missing limb(s)

Base.name: Hypertheymesia
Base.description1: the condition of possessing an extremely detailed autobiographical memory and remembering a vast number of life experiences
Base.description2: people with hyperthymesia spend excessive amounts of time thinking about their past
Base.description3: they can recall almost every day of their lives in near perfect detail

Base.name: Eidetic Memory
Base.description1: the ability to vividly recall images from memory after only a few instances of exposure without using a mnemonic device
Base.description2: it is sometimes erroneously called photographic memory
Base.description3: eidetic memory is reported to occur in a small number of children, not usually in adults

Base.name: Down Syndrome
Base.description1: Down syndrome is a congenital difference
Base.description2: this difference includes lower intellectual and physical variations including short stature and broad facial profile
Base.description3: people with Down syndrome are often more nurturing and have greater well-being

Base.name: Dwarfism
Base.description1: a condition that causes slow growth, affecting the height of an individual and results in short stature
Base.description2: people with dwarfism often struggle with social prejudice due to their height, as well as difficulties in day-to-day tasks such as driving
Base.description3: the terms 'dwarf', 'little person', 'LP', and 'person of short stature' are now generally considered acceptable by most people affected by these disorders

Base.name: Arthritis
Base.description1: painful inflammation and stiffness of the joints
Base.description2: arthritis can decrease one’s range of motion, making it difficult to complete daily tasks
Base.description3: the disease becomes more common with age

Base.name: Narcolepsy
Base.description1: people with this difference experience excessive daytime fatigue, and disturbed routine sleep
Base.description2: people with narcolepsy may feel drowsy or fall asleep at undesirable times of the day
Base.description3: PLACEHOLDER

Base.name: Epilepsy
Base.description1: epilepsy is abnormal activity of the brain cells
Base.description2: it results in unprovoked seizures
Base.description3: epilepsy symptoms include temporary confusion, staring spells, uncontrollable jerking movements and loss of consciousness or awareness

Base.name: Blindness
Base.description1: condition of poor visual perception or complete loss of vision
Base.description2: people with this difference may experience their other senses overcompensate and become stronger
Base.description3: people with this difference may use different tools to help them with their daily life; these can include guide dogs or canes

Base.name: Depression
Base.description1: depression disrupts a person’s daily functional abilities
Base.description2: depression can induce people to be over critical and they may seem like they are unable to have fun
Base.description3: people can feel hopeless, sad, irritable or have a lack of energy and self-esteem

Base.name: Amnesia
Base.description1: amnesia is a loss of whole or partial memory
Base.description2: loss ranges from particular facts of information to an inability to transfer information into long term memory
Base.description3: people with this difference can learn new information, but may not remember the act of learning new information

Base.name: Anosmia
Base.description1: anosmia is the complete absence of the sense of smell
Base.description2: can be a temporary or permanent condition
Base.description3: can affect loss of appetite, smell memory and libido

Base.name: Autism
Base.description1: people with autism have a range of intelligence
Base.description2: people with autism often have a particularly keen interest in specific items or information
Base.description3: they can sometimes have a strong reaction to stimuli

Base.name: Ageusia
Base.description1: ageusia is the inability to detect tastes, such as sweetness, sourness, bitterness, saltiness and umami
Base.description2: this loss of east can be caused by neurological damage, problems with the endocrine system, tobacco use and aging
Base.description3: the tongue can only sense texture and tastes, most of what is perceived as the sense of taste is derived from smell

Base.name: Synesthesia
Base.description1: a crossing of neurological pathways where stimuli that usually affect one sense can involuntarily trigger another
Base.description2: a common form of synesthesia causes the individual to perceive numbers and letters as intrinsically coloured
Base.description3: PLACEHOLDER
